summary_points: 1. Welltower Inc. entered into a new equity distribution agreement on March 28, 2025, allowing for the offer and sale of up to $7,500,000,000 of common stock through various sales agents and forward sellers.
2.  This new agreement, effective March 28, 2025, replaced a prior equity distribution agreement dated October 29, 2024.
3. The agreement allows for the possibility of the company owing cash or shares of common stock to forward purchasers under certain circumstances (e.g. cash settlement or net share settlement).

1. Discover Financial Services entered into a letter agreement with J. Michael Shepherd on March 27, 2025, outlining his continued service as Interim CEO and President until June 30, 2025, or the closing of the merger with Capital One, whichever comes first.

2.  Shepherd's compensation includes a base salary of $1,750,000 for April and $750,000 for May and June 2025, plus a potential one-time $2,400,000 merger completion bonus if the merger closes by June 30, 2025.

3.  The agreement specifies that Shepherd will not receive severance pay beyond what is explicitly stated in the agreement, and any disputes regarding "cause" for termination will be subject to de novo review.
1. Ecolab Inc. amended and restated its $2.0 billion unsecured 5-year revolving credit facility, extending the maturity date from April 2026 to March 2030.
2.  The amended credit agreement includes a $100 million letter of credit subfacility and a $75 million swing line loan subfacility.
3. The agreement contains a financial covenant requiring Ecolab to maintain a minimum interest expense coverage ratio, measured at the end of each four-quarter period.
1. Ecolab Inc. reorganized its operating segments effective January 1, 2025, resulting in seven operating segments instead of the previous structure.
2.  For the year ended December 31, 2024, Ecolab reported total GAAP net sales of $15,741.4 million, compared to $15,320.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2023.
3.  The provided financial information in Exhibits 99.1 and 99.2 is supplemental and does not replace information found in previously filed 10-Q and 10-K reports.
1. On March 25, 2025, Clorox entered into a new $1,200,000,000 five-year unsecured revolving credit agreement, replacing an existing agreement that matured on March 25, 2027.
2.  The new credit agreement includes a consolidated interest coverage ratio as its only financial covenant.

3. The interest rate on borrowings under the new agreement can be calculated using either the base rate, which incorporates the Prime Rate and SOFR, or a rate based solely on the Term SOFR Rate, plus applicable margins depending on Clorox's credit rating.

1. Dollar Tree, Inc. agreed to sell all outstanding membership interests in Family Dollar Stores, LLC for $1,007,500,000 in cash, subject to adjustments based on cash, debt, expenses, and net working capital at closing.
2.  Dollar Tree expects the closing of the Family Dollar sale to occur in the second quarter of 2025 (as of March 28, 2025).
3. If the purchase agreement is terminated under certain circumstances before September 23, 2025, Dollar Tree will receive a $55,412,500 termination fee, guaranteed by Brigade Capital Management, LP.
1. Peter S. Norgeot, Jr. will retire as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer of Entergy Corporation and from his board positions at several subsidiaries on April 30, 2025.
2. Kimberly Cook-Nelson will be appointed as the new Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer on May 1, 2025, with an annual base salary of $745,000.

3.  Ms. Cook-Nelson's compensation will also include an annual cash bonus targeted at 80% of her base salary and performance units, restricted stock, and stock options under the company's incentive plan.

1. Vertex Pharmaceuticals announced on March 28, 2025, that its VX-264 type 1 diabetes program will not advance past Phase 1/2 trials, resulting in a projected $400 million non-cash impairment charge to first-quarter and full-year 2025 GAAP operating expenses.
2.  The termination of the VX-264 program represents a significant setback for Vertex's type 1 diabetes portfolio.
3.  Vertex plans to finalize and disclose the results of its impairment analysis in its Form 10-Q filing for the quarter ending March 31, 2025.
1. On March 27, 2025, Julie A. Schertell resigned from Ingersoll Rand Inc.'s Board of Directors, Nominating and Corporate Governance Committee, and Sustainability Committee.
2. The filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a significant event requiring immediate disclosure to the SEC.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are explicitly mentioned in the provided excerpt.

1. Intel Corporation completed the second closing of the sale of its NAND memory technology and manufacturing business to SK hynix on March 27, 2025, receiving approximately $1.9 billion net of adjustments.
2.  The NAND wafer manufacturing and sale agreement between Intel and SK hynix, in place since December 29, 2021, terminated with the second closing.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this filing beyond the termination of the previously disclosed agreement.
1. News Corp repurchased approximately US$654,044,743.04 worth of Class A and Class B shares as of March 27, 2025, under a US$1 billion stock repurchase program.
2. On March 27, 2025, News Corp repurchased 21,366,316 Class A shares and 10,543,668 Class B shares, at a highest price of US$30.69 and US$35.25 respectively.
3. News Corp's stock repurchase program intends to enhance shareholder value, but future repurchases are subject to market conditions and other factors.
1. On March 27, 2025, Jacobs Solutions Inc. acted as guarantor in a two-year term loan agreement with Jacobs Engineering Group Inc. for $200 million and £410 million.
2.  The agreement involved repaying a previous loan of $120,499,395.60 and £411,869,423.95 in full.

3. The interest rate on the new loan varies between a SONIA or term SOFR rate plus a margin of 0.875%–1.50% or a base rate plus 0.00%–0.50%, depending on Jacobs Engineering Group Inc.’s leverage ratio.
1. Dell Technologies Inc. issued $4,000,000,000 in senior notes with maturities ranging from 2028 to 2035, at varying interest rates and offering prices, with the closing expected on April 1, 2025.
2.  The notes were sold at a discount, with the 2035 Notes having the lowest offering price at 99.681% of their principal amount, indicating a higher yield for investors.
3. Net proceeds from the note sale will be used for general corporate purposes, which may include debt repayment,  suggesting potential future impact on the company's debt levels.
1. On March 27, 2025, T-Mobile US, Inc. closed a public offering of $3.5 billion in senior notes with varying maturity dates (2032, 2035, and 2055).
2. The net proceeds from the note sale, totaling $3.5 billion, are expected to be used for general corporate purposes, including share repurchases, dividends, and refinancing existing debt.
3.  The offering was underwritten by several firms, including Barclays Capital Inc., Deutsche Bank Securities Inc., Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, and UBS Securities LLC, acting as representatives.
1. VICI Properties Inc. and VICI Properties L.P. entered into an underwriting agreement on March 26, 2025, to issue and sell $1.3 billion in senior notes due 2028 and 2035.

2.  The offering is expected to generate net proceeds of approximately $1,280.7 million, with VICI LP intending to use $1,299.4 million of the proceeds to repay outstanding debt maturing in May and June 2025.

3. The offering is expected to close on April 7, 2025, subject to customary closing conditions;  any underwriters or their affiliates holding existing VICI debt will receive a portion of the net proceeds, potentially triggering FINRA Rule 5121 if over 5% of proceeds are used for such repayments.
1. On March 26, 2025, Gregory J. Hayes was elected to Becton, Dickinson and Company's Board of Directors, increasing the board size from eleven to twelve members.
2. Mr. Hayes will receive restricted stock units valued at $180,836 upon joining the board.
3.  Mr. Hayes will serve on the Audit Committee and the Compensation and Human Capital Committee.
1. On March 24, 2025, Kimberly J. Harris resigned from Ameren Corporation's Board of Directors due to personal health reasons.
2.  The SEC filing is an 8-K Current Report, indicating a significant event requiring immediate disclosure.
3. No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in this section of the filing.
